biography:
From obituary (Vineyard Gazette Online, May 28, 2004):

Virginia Culver Hipkoe McLean, 79, died at her home in Oak Bluffs on May 14, after a lengthy illness. A longtime resident of Lagoon Pond, she was born on March 7, 1925 in Bellingham, Wash., where she was raised. She was graduated from the University of Washington with a degree in English.

While attending university, she met Dr. Alan A. McLean, 'a prominent psychiatrist, author and leader in the budding field of applied industrial psychiatry'. She worked in New York editing original articles and abstracts of literature in this emerging field.

On the Island, she worked for several years at the Vineyard Haven Library until her retirement in 1994. At work she would often surprise the unsuspecting with her wry, often cynical wit. She had a distinctly offbeat sense of humor. She worked in various sections of the library, finishing her career there in the children's section.

Virginia volunteered her time to promote civic involvement, serving as president of the Martha's Vineyard League of Women's Voters from 1978 to 1980. She was also president of the Eastville-Lagoon Association in the 1980s and an active member of the Vineyard Committee on Hunger, joining soon after its founding in 1975 and serving as its president from 1990 to 1995.

She is survived by her sons, Richard McLean of Oak Bluffs and Robert McLean of Toronto, Canada; granddaughters Sarah McLean and Emily McLean.
miscellaneous: Graduate of University of Washington (English). Worked as editor in industrial psychiatry field. Longtime resident of Martha's Vineyard. Known for wry, cynical wit and offbeat sense of humor.
